results.title: Nature's landscapes
results.creator_credit: ABC-TV (Australia). Natural History Unit and Klaus Toft
results.brief_description: This is a stunning visual journey through Australia’s natural environment, accompanied by evocative and beautiful classical music with natural sound effects. Soar across harsh and unforgiving deserts, plunge into turbulent seas and delve into ancient, lush forests… be swept along with the sights and sounds of this majestic and beautiful land. Featuring the music of Tchaikovsky, Vivaldi, Mozart and other classical masters, this is an imaginative marriage of breathtaking images and sound.

results.title: Nature's fury
results.brief_description: Earthquakes, hurricanes, tornadoes and floods - these colossal powers of nature have had dramatic consequences for human kind. Learn how earthquakes create and shape our landscapes, even as they destroy life and property. Discover how rotating updrafts can build into the towering tornadoes, and how cloud disturbances can grow into awesome hurricanes. As massive as these forces are, the stories of human heroism and tragedy are very personal, meet heroes, fighting to save their homes and lives, and meet the scientists as they study the elemental killers, in an effort to predict, prepare and protect ourselves from nature’s fury.

results.title: Nature's forge
results.brief_description: Examines the ecological effects of the release of excess heat from power plants. Shows research being done to study the effect of heat from nuclear power plants on fish, plants and animals.

results.title: Nature's food chain
results.brief_description: Nature’s food is a delicately balanced system of inter-relationships. This emphasises the importance of predators in maintaining the balance of nature. Describes the three main groups of animals, herbivores, carnivores and omnivores.

results.title: Nature's complete food
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
In the rainforests of Central America grows a most unusual tree. It produces nature’s most complete food…the avocado. The avocado tree grows quite happily in temperate Australia, but it doesn’t always produce good crops. CSIRO scientist Dr Margaret Sedgley has been finding out why. The avocado’s erratic behaviour seems due to adverse temperatures. CSIRO’s research has focused on the two most important varieties - smooth-skinned Fuerte, and rough-skinned hass. North-western Victoria is an important new area for avocado growing. Here the researchers are looking at another problem. Irrigation water from the Murray may cause salt damage to trees at certain times of the year. Whether it’s possible to solve some of these problems of growing avocados in Australian conditions, only time and further research will tell.

results.title: Nature's builders
results.creator_credit: Educational Media International and Ken J. Widdowson
results.brief_description: A simple introductory program that looks at three of nature’s builders: the swallow, the spider, and the caterpillar. Shows how they instinctively go about constructing their homes and indicates the purpose of each home.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Educational Media International and Ken J. Widdowson

results.title: Nature's bounty: flowers for the Japanese
results.brief_description: Flowers and their place in Japanese life, art, customs and tradition. A love of flowers is taught from earliest childhood and influences much of Japanese culture: in landscape gardening, growing “bonsai” plants, the “ikebana” style of arranging flowers, in works of art, in designs for the kimono. Different blossoms mark the rhythm of the seasons in the parks and gardens of Japan.

results.title: Naturally it's rubber
results.creator_credit: British Information Services, James Carr and Peter Hopkinson
results.brief_description: Tells the story of natural rubber - the rubber industry of Malaya, showing research and improvement of productivity. Shows how the rubber tree is cultivated and how the latex is collected and made into rubber on Malaysian plantations and small holdings. Also shows some of the numerous applications, from elastic yarn for swimsuits to springs for cars and how research has helped to produce many types of natural rubber compounds for different purposes.

results.title: Natural solution
results.brief_description: Shows a program of biological control which uses an imported insect to attack the introduced Water Hyacinth, a weed clogging many Australian waters.

results.title: Natural selection
results.brief_description: Discusses the impact of the theory of evolution, emphasizing the concept of nautral selection. Shows how studies by biologists carried out on moths, mosquitioes and plants provide evidence of natural selection. Reports on three experiments concerning the role of natural selection in evolution: a study in bird predation as a factor in the survival of variant species of moths at Oxford University; a study of natural selection among plant populations at Carnegie Institute; and a study of the resistance of mosquitoes to modern insecticides at the University of Western Ontario.
